moves: 1. c4 c6 2. e4 d5 3. exd5 Nf6 4. Nc3 cxd5 5. d4 e6 6. Nf3 Bb4 7. cxd5 Nxd5 8. Qc2 Qc7 9. Bd2 Nd7
comment:
Positions with the isolated d-pawn are quite popular in New Delhi
and a number of very interesting games on this topic have been played here.

moves: 1. c4 c6 2. e4 d5 3. exd5 Nf6 4. Nc3 cxd5 5. d4 e6 6. Nf3 Bb4 7. cxd5 Nxd5 8. Qc2 Qc7 9. Bd2 Nd7 10. Bd3 Bxc3 11. bxc3 N5f6 12. a4
comment:
Perhaps White anticipated ...b6 and thus
planned creating tension on the queenside with a4-a5. However this move wastes
time and allows Black to develop his pieces comfortably.

moves: 1. c4 c6 2. e4 d5 3. exd5 Nf6 4. Nc3 cxd5 5. d4 e6 6. Nf3 Bb4 7. cxd5 Nxd5 8. Qc2 Qc7 9. Bd2 Nd7 10. Bd3 Bxc3 11. bxc3 N5f6 12. a4 b6 13. O-O Bb7 14. Nh4 O-O 15. f4 Bd5 16. Nf3 Bc4
comment:
Now light squares in White's camp are weak, while his
dark-squared bishop is an unfortunate piece.

moves: 1. c4 c6 2. e4 d5 3. exd5 Nf6 4. Nc3 cxd5 5. d4 e6 6. Nf3 Bb4 7. cxd5 Nxd5 8. Qc2 Qc7 9. Bd2 Nd7 10. Bd3 Bxc3 11. bxc3 N5f6 12. a4 b6 13. O-O Bb7 14. Nh4 O-O 15. f4 Bd5 16. Nf3 Bc4 17. Ne5 Bxd3 18. Qxd3 Rac8 19. Rf3 Nd5 20. Qb5 Rfd8 21. Raf1 f5 22. Be1 Nxe5 23. fxe5 Qc4
comment:
This is a triumph of Black's strategy - his
position is winning, although of course White should not have collapsed so
quickly...
